This parameterisation is empirical but it reflects the real processes operating within the thermal aureole of the sill quite closely. The cumulative mass of carbon generated must increase until it tends to a constant value when the sill has cooled sufficiently to inhibit further maturation reactions. The analytical solution for conductive heating of the host rock shows that the thermal front moves outwards as a power law with p = 0.5 (ref.
27 ). Initially, we expect the thermogenic reaction front to move out from the sill at a similar rate to the thermal front but with a p exponent slightly >0.5 because reactions can take place at lower temperatures when more time is available.
